narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about Tokyo.
Knowledge about Tokyo and the greater humanities in post-Meiji Japan
Knowledge about tokyo
Writing, and reading analytically.

I learned about the history of Tokyo through the Edo, Meiji, Taisho, Showa, and early postwar periods up into the present day. I learned about the dark and gritty side of Tokyo's criminal underworld, the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923 (and the resulting fires), major aspects of Japanese culture, Tokyo's districts such as Harajuku, as well as their modern day but longstanding crow problem.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The lectures were a little dry so it was hard to be engaged for the whole time, but I'm sure that's not a problem when the class is taught in Tokyo.

Strengths: content
Weakness: length of the discussion. 3 hours is too long
The variety of media implemented in the course was truly engaging.

I loved the course, and I loved the way that the professor this year decided to begin the class with the film "Tokyo Waka" about Japan's crow problem (which he usually saves for the end). I think the contrast between the first few reading assignments about the seemingly-ancient Edo period and the modern-day Tokyo portrayed in this film allowed me to make good comparisons between the old and new, with the development story between these two periods being filled in by the rest of the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they were into Japanese culture and wanted to get a better look into that/ Tokyo specifically then I would recommend this class.
Absolutely
Yes because it provides one with a different lens of Tokyo.
Yes! The history of Tokyo is incredibly interesting.
